inlineContent.text: üíª Check: üõ†Ô∏è Builds, Runs. Enter a random invalid IP address, and press
This won‚Äôt work yet, because we haven‚Äôt discussed having a valid CloudXR server! But you should see some activity in the Xcode console log, and eventually a log line containing:

code: NVSC LIBRARY method 'nvstConnectToServer' has not returned in 10 seconds.

inlineContent.text: This means that CloudXR‚Äôs streaming library was unable to connect, but that it at least tried!
I largely consider this part ouf of scope. From now on, I‚Äôll assume you have a CloudXRServerSample.exe server running at a known IP address.
In order for CloudXR to stream, it needs the current space to be a RealityKit ImmersiveSpace that is properly ‚Äúhooked up‚Äù.

content.text: Debug stuff that doesn‚Äôt fit here
‚ùåError: Compiling for visionOS 1.1, but module ‚ÄòRealityKitContent‚Äô has a minimum deployment target of visionOS 2.0: ‚Ä¶

inlineContent.text: This error occurs because Xcode‚Äôs generated application has a package RealityKitContent which requires visionOS 2.0, but CloudXRKit was compiled with a RealityKitContent package with visionOS  1.1.
This error, if it happens, should be triggered on the first build done after you
The worarkound is to edit the
file inside your Xcode application‚Äôs RealityKitContent package. Set the version to the string ‚Äú1.1‚Äù:
You might now want or need all of them, but these are a good default set for an IP address field.
because IP addresses aren‚Äôt words to be spell checked
because IP addresse are easier to enter on a number pad
require a numeric entry (e.g., if your server has a alphanumeric host name) you don‚Äôt want to accidentally capitalize things
because you might want to speak the IP address in the headset rather than using an awkward spatial keyboard.
allows you to do validation/cleanup of the entry, such as the whitespace trimming done here.
